Old English Bede begins. Initial and first words not inserted.
A bit of ornament in the margin. Nothing more till p. 161 where is an initial in fine outline with a human figure hanging by the neck. The next is at p. 175

Initial (Liber IV) in outline, the first of a numerous and very pretty series.

supportDesc.foliation: ff. a-b + i + pp. 1-490 + ff. c-d
supportDesc.collation: 1 modern flyleaf, 1826 38 -128 1310(4 canc.) 148 -308 316 (wants 6), 1 flyleaf modern. The first quire with an old mark is F (6); this marking goes to M or perhaps N (13): 14 is marked A; this marking runs to R(30): 31 has no mark.

handDesc.handNote: Two principal hands of which one is remarkably large. Both are clear and black.

decoDesc.decoNote: The ornamentation of this book is interesting. It consists chiefly of decorative initials which are irregularly inserted. They are in outline: a faint wash of red has been applied in some cases. In many instances the pencil sketch (afterwards executed in ink) is visible.

physDesc.additions:
The margins have been utilized for the transcription of a good many interesting texts. Some of these (especially the Salomon and Saturn ) are well known. I do not think that a complete list has been given, and I attempt one here.
Wanley
( Cat.
p. 114) takes account of the Anglo-Saxon passages only.
: Incipit: "bletsung to candelun.“ Domine Iesu Christe creator celi” , etc. Text in Latin, ending p.7, with excipit: “Deus omnipotens tua nos protectione custodi” , etc. “his peractis cantetur”
Antiphon : “Haue gratia plena. Sancti Simeonis collecta. Erudi quesumus domine”
Masses for Sexagesima and Quinquagesima ,continued on following pages(p. 13 Feria iii infra quinquag., p. 14 Sabbatum)
Dom. in(i)tium xl (1st Sun. in Lent). Masses, continued up to Good Friday (p.36). Marginalia resumes on after a break on 37

I 382 The lines from “Christus illum” to “defendat deus” are the last stanzas, very corruptly written, of the
Hymn of SS. Sechnall or Secundinus on St Patrick
, of which only four complete copies are known. This fragment has not been noticed. Special efficacy was attached to the stanzas here quoted. See Bernard and Atkinson
(The Irish Liber Hymnorum)

The Crucifixion of Christ The Passion of Christ Crucifixion scene Christ on the Cross surrounded and partly written over by later text, is part of a fine figure of Christ crucified: it lacks the left arm. The head is bearded, the Cross not drawn
The Passion of Christ Homily
The Passion of Our Lord Following the end of the text. Homily giving the story of the Passion. “Men ðe gehirað nu hu (space) drihten wæs sprecende on þas tid to his geferum” . Copied for Professor
Napier
: apparently only here
485 Figure Cherub-like Figure On the next page is a small nude figure (also written over) standing on rocky ground and holding up his hands, spread out on a level with his shoulders
488
Leofric inscription Unimportant scribbles. Above the Leofric -inscription is: “Atte le”

history.provenance:
The volume was one of those given by Leofric to Exeter . On 488is his inscription in good round miniscules , in Latin and Anglo-Saxon: “Hunc librum dat leofricus episcopus ecclesie sancti petri apostoli in exonia ubi sedes episcopalis est ad utilitatem successorum suorum. Si quis illum abstulerit inde, subiaceat maledictioni. FIAT. FIAT. FIAT." "Ðas boc gef Leofric . b. into sce petres mynstre on exancestre þaer se bisceopstol is for (his) sawle alisednysse 7 gif hig hwa ut æt brede god hine fordo on þære e ...” It is not entered in the list of Leofric's gifts contained in the Bodleian MS. Auct. D. 2. 16 and printed by
Dugdale,
Wanley,
Warren
(Leofric Missal) etc.
